docs.snippet: While much of the nation was preoccupied with the Super Bowl Sunday evening, Herschel Walker watched only parts of the game, with little interest and no jealousy, he said. The only part of the game that caught his eye was Marcus Allen's 74-yard ro...
docs.lead_paragraph: While much of the nation was preoccupied with the Super Bowl Sunday evening, Herschel Walker watched only parts of the game, with little interest and no jealousy, he said. The only part of the game that caught his eye was Marcus Allen's 74-yard romp for a touchdown. As a track sprinter who enjoys the feeling of running ahead of the pack, Walker appreciated Allen's jaunt through the Washington Redskins. But Walker said he never felt pangs that he should be part of the big show of that other league.

headline.main: Sports of The Times; Walker's Second Season

docs.snippet: IN ''Nine Sinatra Songs,'' which    had its New York premiere last   night, Twyla Tharp managed to   turn truism into a triumph. How she did this is one of the surprises Miss Tharp and her dance company, which opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Mus...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN ''Nine Sinatra Songs,'' which had its New York premiere last night, Twyla Tharp managed to turn truism into a triumph. How she did this is one of the surprises Miss Tharp and her dance company, which opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, provided with two very different premieres and a staple, ''Sue's Leg.'' In a way, this first of three programs offered a mini-retrospective of Miss Tharp's dance concerns. While not complete and not reaching back to her choreographic beginnings in the 1960's, it showed a wider range than usual for a Tharp program. One reason behind the variety would seem to be Miss Tharp's own evolution, her shift toward styles and esthetics that are new to her if not necessarily new to others.

headline.main: DANCE: 2 PREMIERES BY TWYLA THARP IN BROOKLYN

docs.snippet: Some passages from current and recently published books that we find particularly appealing.     Primal Scream      Even if Elizabeth Bishop had never written a line of poetry, her ''Collected Prose'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux) would be enough to g...
docs.lead_paragraph: Some passages from current and recently published books that we find particularly appealing. Primal Scream Even if Elizabeth Bishop had never written a line of poetry, her ''Collected Prose'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux) would be enough to give her a lasting reputation. One of her great gifts was an ability to convey with singular purity both the terror and the wonder of childhood, particularly when writing about the Nova Scotia village where she spent her early years. A scream, the echo of a scream, hangs over that Nova Scotian village. No one hears it; it hangs there forever, a slight stain in those pure blue skies, skies that travelers compare to those of Switzerland, too dark, too blue, so that they seem to keep on darkening a little more around the horizon - or is it around the rims of the eyes? - the color of the cloud of bloom on the elm trees, the violet on the fields of oats; something darkening over the woods and waters as well as the sky. The scream hangs like that, unheard, in memory - in the past, in the present, and those years between. It was not even loud to begin with, perhaps. It just came there to live, forever - not aloud, just alive forever. Its pitch would be the pitch of my village. Flick the lightning rod on top of the church steeple with your fingernail and you will hear it. Exit the King

docs.snippet: Fordham, scoring its final 8 points from the foul line, handed Manhattan its sixth straight defeat in Metro Atlantic Conference play, 69-65, at Rose Hill Gymnasium yesterday.    George Jones, who made 4 free throws down the stretch, scored twice f...
docs.lead_paragraph: Fordham, scoring its final 8 points from the foul line, handed Manhattan its sixth straight defeat in Metro Atlantic Conference play, 69-65, at Rose Hill Gymnasium yesterday. George Jones, who made 4 free throws down the stretch, scored twice from the line with 1 minute 40 seconds to play to put the Rams ahead to stay, 63-61. Steve Samuels, Jones and Don McCormick each scored two foul shots to seal the victory.

docs.snippet: Thomas Keneally is an Australian writer whose most recent book is ''Schindler's List,'' which deals with the rescue of a number of Polish Jews in Krakow during World War II.  ROMAN By Roman Polanski.  Illustrated. 461 pp. New York: William Morrow ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Thomas Keneally is an Australian writer whose most recent book is ''Schindler's List,'' which deals with the rescue of a number of Polish Jews in Krakow during World War II. ROMAN By Roman Polanski. Illustrated. 461 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $17.95. By Thomas Keneally THE idea of writing a history of his life came to Roman Polanski when in 1981 he was visiting the Polish village of Wysoka. There as a child he had found refuge from the Nazis with the family of an impoverished farmer, during the period between the liquidation of the Krakow ghetto in March 1943 and the parlous liberation of Poland by the Russians at the end of World War II. Most Polish patriots see a parallel between the episodes of their own lives and the tragic phases of their country's history, and Mr. Polanski says he was further encouraged to tell his story, the story of a Polish traveler in a large and dangerous world, by the imposition of martial law in Poland late in 1981.

docs.snippet: ''The Tale of the Frog Prince''; ''Sleeping Beauty''; ''Goldilocks and the Three Bears''; ''Jack and the Beanstalk''; ''Rapunzel.'' CBS/Fox Video Approximately 50 minutes per story. $39.98 each cassette    Once upon a time, in a kingdom far, far a...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Tale of the Frog Prince''; ''Sleeping Beauty''; ''Goldilocks and the Three Bears''; ''Jack and the Beanstalk''; ''Rapunzel.'' CBS/Fox Video Approximately 50 minutes per story. $39.98 each cassette Once upon a time, in a kingdom far, far away but fairly close to Malibu, an actress named Shelley Duvall set out to dramatize a series of fairy tales for a pay-cable service. As everyone knows, Miss Duvall is the spindly- looking one in all those Robert Altman movies; as everyone may not know, Miss Duvall has been a collector of antique fairy-tale volumes since the age of 17.

headline.main: Faerie Tale; HOME VIDEO; CLASSICS ON CASSETTES: FAIRY TALES, CHEKHOVAND A CHILLER

docs.snippet: By 6 P.M. the chilly aisles at the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 67th Street were crowded with visitors who felt more comfortable wearing their overcoats, down coats or lynx, mink, sable and fox coats. Last night, over 2,500 people ha...
docs.lead_paragraph: By 6 P.M. the chilly aisles at the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 67th Street were crowded with visitors who felt more comfortable wearing their overcoats, down coats or lynx, mink, sable and fox coats. Last night, over 2,500 people had purchased $150 tickets for the patrons' party and $90 tickets for the preview party - both events which marked the opening of the Annual Winter Antiques Show. ''This year, everyone seemed to want to get here early to get a chance to buy the things first and also see everyone else,'' said Pam Sarnoff who, with Nancy Fowler, is co-chairman of the party committee. The show opens today and continues through Jan. 29. Admission is $6.

docs.snippet: Oscar Mayer & Company has cut its stake in Prima Meat Packers Ltd. of Japan to 10.04 percent, from 24.85 percent, Prima said today. Oscar Mayer, a unit of the General Foods Corporation, sold 14.8 percent of Prima's stock Wednesday to 13 Japanese c...
docs.lead_paragraph: Oscar Mayer & Company has cut its stake in Prima Meat Packers Ltd. of Japan to 10.04 percent, from 24.85 percent, Prima said today. Oscar Mayer, a unit of the General Foods Corporation, sold 14.8 percent of Prima's stock Wednesday to 13 Japanese concerns, including C. Itoh & Company.

docs.snippet: PEOPLE dispirited by snow, slush and sleet tend toward reveries of sun-soaked beaches and lush greenswards. It is such fancies as these that New Yorkers can indulge in to their hearts' content during a 12-week round-the-world film retrospective be...
docs.lead_paragraph: PEOPLE dispirited by snow, slush and sleet tend toward reveries of sun-soaked beaches and lush greenswards. It is such fancies as these that New Yorkers can indulge in to their hearts' content during a 12-week round-the-world film retrospective beginning Sunday at the Regency Theater, Broadway and 67th Street. The series offers 59 movies produced from 1922 (''Nanook of the North'') to 1979 (''Tess''), about half of them in Technicolor and all but five long ones in double bills. The action roams from Argentina to Afghanistan and Australia, with frequent side trips to Paris, London and Rome. The films will be at the Regency (724- 3700) through April 7. The criterion for the entries was ''movies with distinctive locations that advance the plot,'' according to Frank Rowley, who has charted 43 thematic retrospectives as the theater's programmer-manager since 1976. The top admission charge is $5, and a $15 series card is available for five admissions.

headline.main: Photo of film ''Around The World In 80 Days''

docs.snippet: Winners and losers in Hollywood are determined as much by expectations as by results.    Among the major movies of 1983, ''Superman III,'' for example, was widely felt to be a failure, although it was the fifth most successful movie of the year an...
docs.lead_paragraph: Winners and losers in Hollywood are determined as much by expectations as by results. Among the major movies of 1983, ''Superman III,'' for example, was widely felt to be a failure, although it was the fifth most successful movie of the year and earned Warner Bros. $36.4 million in film rentals. A lightweight comedy called ''Mr. Mom,'' in ninth place with $31.5 million in film rentals, however, was considered a major success by the movie industry. ''Mr. Mom,'' which starred Michael Keaton as a husband who stays home with the kids, was not given much chance to survive, even by its distributor, 20th Century-Fox. Conversely, ''Superman II'' had earned more than $65 million in film rentals; Warner Bros. hoped for as much from its sequel. In the end, ''Mr. Mom,'' at a cost of approximately $8 million, was considerably more profitable than ''Superman III,'' which cost more than $35 million.
